A **dwarvish mattock** is a type of [weapon](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a [two-handed](/wiki/Two-handed "Two-handed") [weapon-tool](/wiki/Weapon-tool "Weapon-tool") that is made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron") and uses the [pick-axe](/wiki/Pick-axe "Pick-axe") [skill](/wiki/Skill "Skill"), and appears as a **broad pick** when [unidentified](/wiki/Identification "Identification").

[ ]

## Generation

[Dwarven](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)") characters start the game with knowledge of the dwarvish mattock. There is a line of code that gives any dwarven character in a role starting with a pick-axe a dwarvish mattock instead, though the line is currently commented-out.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

Dwarvish mattocks make up about 1.3% of all randomly generated weapons. General [stores](/wiki/Store "Store"), antique weapon outlets and used armor dealerships can sell dwarvish mattocks.

Live [dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster_attribute\) "Dwarf (monster attribute)") generated with a [dwarvish short sword](/wiki/Dwarvish_short_sword "Dwarvish short sword") and [dwarvish iron helm](/wiki/Dwarvish_iron_helm "Dwarvish iron helm") have an effective 1⁄8 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a dwarvish mattock.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) [Watchmen](/wiki/Watchmen "Watchmen") and [soldiers](/wiki/Soldier "Soldier") that generate with a [polearm](/wiki/Polearm "Polearm") as their primary weapon (1⁄3 chance) may receive dwarvish mattocks.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

[Player monsters](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster"), including those on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane"), have a \~1.1% chance of generating with a dwarvish mattock as their initial weapon before role-based replacements.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit da859c5e](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/da859c5eb88e17d04ec2bb37e2c12842e9f4c4a9), mattocks no longer generate as starting weapons on watchmen and soldiers.

## Description

As with a pick-axe, a dwarvish mattock can be [applied](/wiki/Applied "Applied") or [wielded](/wiki/Wield "Wield") to [dig](/wiki/Dig "Dig") through walls or floors, as well as break [boulders](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder") and [statues](/wiki/Statue "Statue"); shopkeepers will also prevent you from entering a shop with a mattock in your inventory. Buying or selling a dwarvish mattock will [auto-identify](/wiki/Auto-identify "Auto-identify") it, as will attempting to enter a [shop](/wiki/Shop "Shop") with one, or else removing it from a container in your inventory while inside.

## Strategy

A dwarvish mattock can be an effective weapon, as it deals far more damage than a pick-axe, especially against larger monsters - it is also much heavier and requires both hands free to wield, and their -1 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") penalty can make hitting with one difficult early in the game until you boost your [Luck](/wiki/Luck "Luck"). [Archeologists](/wiki/Archeologist "Archeologist") and other roles planning to utilize a mattock as their primary weapon can use their starting pick-axe and train to Skilled to offset the penalty.

As with a pick-axe, applying a mattock to wield it does not use up a turn, which can be advantageous when combined with other wielded items: as an example, you can apply a [bullwhip](/wiki/Bullwhip "Bullwhip") at a monster to disarm it, then immediately attack on your next turn by applying a mattock, without having to take a turn to wield it.

Enchanted mattocks are among the best naturally-occurring weapons that can be given to a [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong") [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") with a weapon attack - they are also the deadliest weapon that early characters and pets can encounter, where they are in the hands of hostile dwarves that can do upwards of 20 damage per swing.

### Average damage calculation

The average damage calculations in the following table do not include bonuses from [weapon skills](/wiki/Skill "Skill"), [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength"), or from using a [blessed](/wiki/Blessed "Blessed") weapon against [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") or [demons](/wiki/M2_DEMON "M2 DEMON").

| Weapon              | Small monster                                                                            | Large monster                                                                                          |
| ------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| +0 dwarvish mattock | ![\frac{1+12}{2}=\bold{6.5}](/images/math/e/d/0/ed0dbd7a7d4bbf929b6f9767db74f598.png)    | ![\frac{1+8}{2}+\frac{2+12}{2}=\bold{11.5}](/images/math/5/f/4/5f48278ea553362df7220cbb53cb3490.png)   |
| +7 dwarvish mattock | ![\frac{1+12}{2}+7=\bold{13.5}](/images/math/4/8/8/4882ad39b5573c014a1c1b0c2eb9fd1e.png) | ![\frac{1+8}{2}+\frac{2+12}{2}+7=\bold{18.5}](/images/math/c/1/b/c1be13a94aeb47cfe45e6339035ef92f.png) |

## History

The dwarvish mattock first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [upgrading](/wiki/Upgrading "Upgrading") a pick-axe will produce a dwarvish mattock and vice versa.

Upgrading makes it possible to enchant any weapon to +127 by [polymorphing](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") the weapon of choice until it turns into a mattock: the mattock can then be upgraded to a [pick-axe](/wiki/Pick-axe "Pick-axe") and polymorphed again until it becomes a [tinning kit](/wiki/Tinning_kit "Tinning kit") or an [expensive camera](/wiki/Expensive_camera "Expensive camera"); after [charging](/wiki/Charging "Charging") the resulting item until it has 127 charges, it will become a +127 weapon upon reverting completely, since charges and enchantment are stored with the same variable. A +127 [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword") can be turned into [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur") for a lawful character, while a +127 [bow](/wiki/Bow "Bow") or other [launcher](/wiki/Launcher "Launcher") can fire 40 or more projectiles at once.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), the dwarvish mattock can be thrown with no to-hit penalty.

[Slave to Armok](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Slave_to_Armok "DNetHack artifacts") is a lawful [artifact](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") mattock that favors dwarves and grants +1d5 to hit and double damage against [elves](/wiki/Elf_\(monster_attribute\) "Elf (monster attribute)"), [orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(monster_attribute\) "Orc (monster attribute)"), always-peaceful monsters, and [monster lords](/wiki/M2_LORD "M2 LORD") - it is [bloodthirsty](/wiki/Bloodthirsty "Bloodthirsty"), with a [sanity](/wiki/Sanity "Sanity")-based chance of attacking adjacent monsters each turn.

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), a dwarvish mattock can be created by combining a pick-axe and an [axe](/wiki/Axe "Axe") at a [furnace](/wiki/Furnace "Furnace").

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), a dwarvish mattock can be created at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") by combining a [dwarvish short sword](/wiki/Dwarvish_short_sword "Dwarvish short sword") and a pick-axe.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), upgrading a pick-axe will produce a dwarvish mattock and vice versa, as in SLASH'EM, and forging recipes are the same as in EvilHack.

## Encyclopedia entry

A mattock is an agricultural tool similar to a mining pick.  
It is distinguished by the head terminating in a broader blade  
rather than a narrow spike, which makes it particularly suitable  
for breaking up moderately hard ground. ... During the Middle  
Ages of Europe, the mattock served as an improvised shafted  
weapon for the poorer classes.

\[ Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia ]
